metaarea:
This translation of the Therīgāthā is by Caroline A.F. Rhys Davids and was published under the title Psalms of the Sisters, 1909.

The text is in the public domain.

Prepared for SuttaCentral by Ayya Kathrin Vimalañāṇī.

segments.en: “Lo here! a Sister who the fivefold sense Of higher life hath trained and, self-possessed, Herself well held in hand, hath made her way Where lies the Holy Path, where dwells the Bliss Of mastery over action, speech and thought.
Māra. Why now and whereto art thou seen thus garbed And shaven like a nun, yet dost not join Ascetics of some sect, and share their rites? What, futile and infatuate, is thy quest?
Cālā. ’Tis they that are without, caught in the net Of the vain shibboleths on which they lean— ’Tis they that have no knowledge of the Truth, ’Tis they that lack all competence therein.
Lo! in the princely Sākiya clan is born A Buddha, peerless ’mong the sons of men: ’Tis he hath shown the saving Truth to me Which vain opinions doth overpass.
Even the What and Why of ILL, and how Ill comes, and how Ill may be overpassed, E’en by the Ariyan, the Eightfold Path, That leadeth to th’ abating of all Ill.
And I who heard his blessed words abide Fain only and alway to do his will. The Threefold Wisdom have I gotten now, And done the bidding of the Buddha blest.
On every hand the love of sense is slain. And the thick gloom of ignorance is rent In twain. Know this, thou Evil One, avaunt! Here, O Destroyer! shalt thou not prevail.”
